22.text: If I take five pictures into a bunker,

27.text: then this is probably the most unlikely pictures you’d take really.

32.text: When I was 8 years old, they put a man on the moon.

36.text: My memory of it is going, as an infant, into the main assembly hall in Stockport and we looked at this kind of blurred imagery.

47.text: Anyway, this picture is of a man on the moon.

50.text: This image will continually stay with me forever

55.text: and it is without doubt the most profound thing that’s ever happened in my life.

60.text: And that is why it’s a great photo.

67.text: This is Adrian Street, who was a very famous wrestler.

74.text: I think the idea is that this is teenage rebellion, this is like: “I am not the man you wanted me to be”.

84.text: This is father and son taken to the extreme.

87.text: This picture destroys me, look at the dad’s eyes: he kinda loves him, but he’s not sure.

93.text: It’s almost as if you can see the envy in his eyes.

98.text: This photo, probably more than any other one that I’m going to talk about,

104.text: has one other element to it, another dimension to it: you can hear what it’s saying and it’s saying “Hello, hello, I’m back again.”

111.text: And that is exactly what he’s doing.

114.text: The next two pictures I’m gonna show you are both based on Americana, of a very different one.

121.text: This is William Eggleston, he chose to use colour photography in 1970-something, apparently caused a bit of a stir, but not that I’m bothered about that.

132.text: He was very interested in the idea of colour photography.

136.text: He took photos of things that were not worthy of you wasting your money on and he chose to photograph rubbish, but in particular he used flash

148.text: and he photographed under somebody’s bed.

151.text: You can’t really emphasize how important and how ridiculous or how powerful this actually is.

156.text: To photograph under a bed and just the junk of real life, but to use colour on it and to almost waste colour on it and waste flashlight on it -

165.text: it’s one of those beautiful things where so little says so much.

174.text: On a more romantic, sort of Woody Allen, New York, this is William Klein.

183.text: In a way, this is everything isn’t it, it’s like the real world hits the unreal world, and it’s got the Bruce Springsteen-ism Americana car,

192.text: and it’s the idea you’re reflecting something that’s not real in the first place and people are just sort of secondary to it.

200.text: It’s like an Edward Hopper picture in a lot of ways, but with far more light and far more activity.

206.text: But the people are actually doing very little, the reflections are doing all the work in this image.

211.text: Whenever you walk around New York it’s a graphic designer’s dream.

216.text: All you’ll see is one thing bouncing off another, and no one caught that magic like William Klein.

226.text: So I’ve been asked to include a personal photograph, or a photograph I took and this is it.

234.text: This is called “Wartime Coward” and it’s my friend Nick Sanderson, who is no longer with us, and me and Nick played in a band together called Earl Brutus.

246.text: We were asked by a magazine to present ourselves so I took the camera out, Nick put on Romi, his wife’s bra and her stockings,

257.text: and he’s obviously got quite big bollocks and there’s a whole series of photos here that are really powerful.

265.text: And I don’t know, this is probably more a family portrait for me than anything else and that’s why it’s important it be included.

272.text: And I guess, if you were gonna go in a bunker then you would take pictures of people you know and you like.
